author: By Joshua Barone
title: A Top Pianist and a Great Composer Walk Into a Bar …
description: After the pianist, Vikingur Olafsson, asked for a concerto over beers, the composer, John Adams, wrote “After the Fall,” which will now travel the world.
content: A few years ago, during the Ojai Music Festival in California, the pianist Vikingur Olafsson was having a couple of beers with the composer John Adams when he said, “John, you know that you are going to write me a piano concerto, don’t you?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erica L. Green
title: In Farewell Address, Biden Warns of an ‘Oligarchy’ Taking Shape in America
description: President Biden did not explicitly name President-elect Donald J. Trump, but his remarks went straight at the tension at the heart of the incoming White House.
content: President Biden on Wednesday warned that an “oligarchy” of the ultrawealthy was emerging in America, sounding the alarm about unchecked power as he gave a farewell speech to the nation just days before he surrenders office to a man he disdains.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Daniels
title: ‘Nickel Boys’ Awakens Black Cinema’s Time Revolution
description: RaMell Ross, A.V. Rockwell, Raven Jackson and Garrett Bradley are the new Black directors chronicling Black life at a different speed.
content: By bending time and leaning on nonlinear storytelling, “Nickel Boys” joins a recent trend of contemporary Black filmmakers relinquishing the impulse to frame Black stories chronologically.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Yan and Graham Dickie
title: Yonkers, N.Y., More Than an Easy Commute
description: The third largest city in New York has new residential projects in the pipeline and is attracting businesses.
content: Yonkers, the third largest city in New York with a once sleepy downtown, has been attracting new businesses, rental projects and creative spaces, with more planned.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Robbins, Maureen Farrell and Jonathan Weisman
title: Ramaswamy Has a High-Profile Perch and a Raft of Potential Conflicts
description: Vivek Ramaswamy, Elon Musk’s partner in an effort to cut government costs, could make decisions that ultimately make him and his investors richer.
content: Vivek Ramaswamy is the less famous and less wealthy half of the duo of billionaires that President-elect Donald J. Trump has designated to slash government costs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Graff
title: Air Quality Improves Across L.A., but Ash Remains a Threat
description: The fresh air came after days of acrid smoke from wildfires, but officials warned that conditions could rapidly worsen again.
content: The sky was clear over Los Angeles on Tuesday, a welcome respite after acrid smoke from wildfires choked the region last week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karoun Demirjian
title: Joni Ernst Says She Will Vote to Confirm Pete Hegseth
description: The Iowa Republican’s decision dramatically increases the likelihood that Mr. Hegseth will have enough votes to be confirmed as President-elect Donald J. Trump’s defense secretary.
content: Senator Joni Ernst, Republican of Iowa, announced on a local news radio show on Tuesday that she would vote to confirm Pete Hegseth as the next secretary of defense, ending weeks of speculation over whether she would break with President-elect Donald J. Trump over his pick.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elie Honig
title: The Perplexing Case of Pam Bondi
description: The former Florida prosecutor is qualified to be the U.S. attorney general. But will she stand up to Trump when it counts?
content: Donald Trump’s selection of Pam Bondi to be the next attorney general merits caution but not panic. She is amply qualified, on paper, to serve as the nation’s top law enforcement official. But Ms. Bondi’s recent public statements, including her false claims about 2020 election fraud and her vow to prosecute Mr. Trump’s perceived political enemies, raise pressing concerns about whether she possesses the independence and credibility necessary to lead the Department of Justice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Roach
title: Choosing Seeds From 14,000 Varieties? It Just Got Easier.
description: The Exchange, on Seed Savers’ website, pairs the people who save heirlooms with those who want them, all for the price of postage.
content: I’m several hundred heirloom bean varieties deep in the latest seed list I’m browsing, description by description, with no plan to come up for air anytime soon. There are nearly 1,600 types of beans alone in this mother lode called The Exchange, each with its own story of human connection.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: The N.Y.P.D. Has Been in Tumult. Can a New Boss Tame It?
description: Commissioner Jessica S. Tisch is shaking up the Police Department after some of its former leaders, elevated by Mayor Eric Adams, came under scrutiny by federal investigators.
content: In the 1890s, Theodore Roosevelt, then head of the board of police commissioners, scoured New York, reporters in tow, hunting officers in saloons and brothels in what he called “midnight rambles.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edward Wong
title: Rubio Aims to Take on the Axis of Anger: China, Russia, North Korea and Iran
description: The loose arrangement of hostile powers could pose a series of conundrums for President-elect Donald Trump’s pick for secretary of state.
content: Marco Rubio embraces the title of Cold Warrior. His adversary, as he sees it, is not the old Soviet Union, which supported the Communist leaders of Cuba, the island his parents left in 1956. Rather, it is an array of nations working together to undermine American power in the 21st century.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: Is It OK to be Messy?
description: A guest essay argues that we need to embrace our clutter more. Do you agree?
content: Are you messy or neat?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $400,000 Homes in Ohio, Pennsylvania and Louisiana
description: A Greek Revival house in Milan, a condo in Philadelphia and a shotgun-style home in New Orleans.
content: A Greek Revival house built in 1836, on 0.2 acres
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Wilson Andrews and Christine Zhang
title: We’re Sharing the Data Behind Our Detailed 2024 Election Map
description: Our new interactive map features precinct-level results that anyone can download.
content: We’ve published a new interactive map of the 2024 election that shows results by precinct, the most detailed vote data available. The New York Times is also releasing this data set for others to use.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ellen Gabler
title: How a Company Makes Millions Off a Hospital Program Meant to Help the Poor
description: A private business has helped supercharge a controversial federal drug program. Patients and insurers have been left with big bills.
content: Soon after being diagnosed with metastatic breast cancer, Virginia King sat in an outpatient clinic in Santa Fe, N.M., while a nurse injected her with a powerful drug to slow damage to her spine, where the disease had spread.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Estrin
title: Applications Open for the 2025 New York Portfolio Review
description: Apply now for this free event for photographers
content: Applications are now open for the free New York Portfolio Review which is produced by The New York Times photo department, Photoville and the Craig Newmark Graduate School of Journalism at CUNY.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sui-Lee Wee
title: Adviser to Cambodian Leader Is Wanted in Thailand Over Dissident’s Killing
description: The Thai authorities accused an adviser to Hun Sen of hiring the gunman who killed a former Cambodian opposition figure in Bangkok last week.
content: A Thai court issued an arrest warrant for an adviser to the Cambodian strongman Hun Sen on Wednesday, charging him with hiring others to commit “premeditated murder” in the brazen killing of a former Cambodian opposition politician in Bangkok last week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: In Pacific Palisades, proof of a previous life is hard to find.
description: A walk-in shower, its blue tiles shimmering in the sun. A washing machine, charred. Christmas ornaments hanging from a tree.
content: A walk-in shower, its blue tiles shimmering in the sun. A washing machine, charred. Christmas ornaments hanging from a tree.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy
title: Germany’s Economy Shrank Last Year. Here’s How Politicians Plan to Revive It.
description: Candidates in the upcoming federal election are focused on lowering taxes and increasing public spending.
content: Germany’s economic output shrank for a second straight year in 2024, data released Wednesday showed. How to revive it has become a central issue as voters prepare to go to the polls next month to elect a new government.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Graham
title: Southern Methodist University Wants to Sever Ties to Its Church. Can the Church Stop It?
description: The dispute, which some critics say tests the church’s autonomy, reached the Texas Supreme Court on Wednesday for arguments.
content: The Texas Supreme Court heard oral arguments on Wednesday in a battle over whether Southern Methodist University can separate from the United Methodist Church. The university, founded in Dallas by Methodists in the early 20th century, has been trying to extricate itself since 2019 amid turmoil in the denomination over gay clergy and gay marriage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: A House at Auschwitz Opens Its Doors to a Chilling Past
description: The home of the death camp’s wartime commandant, Rudolf Höss, which was the subject of the Oscar-winning movie “The Zone of Interest,” will soon welcome visitors.
content: The mother lived for 42 years in a three-story house overlooking a former gas chamber and a gallows at Auschwitz, sometimes losing sleep at the thought of what had happened on the other side of her garden wall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Wallace-Wells
title: What Does the Palisades Disaster Mean for L.A.’s Future?
description: Do these disasters signal a shift in social conditions?
content: It’s been one week since those in Los Angeles woke up to a generational horror — one sprawling neighborhood effectively eliminated by fire overnight, another devastated by the destruction of more than a thousand buildings and homes, and the city almost immediately submerged in a cloud of retributive finger-pointing and scapegoating so thick it seemed almost intended to distract from the scale of devastation itself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacob Bernstein
title: Access Is Tight Around Kamala Harris’s Los Angeles Home
description: The Brentwood house she shares with Doug Emhoff is in an evacuation zone, but the vice president has been in Washington.
content: Although the wildfires ripping through Los Angeles have not hit Brentwood — a wealthy enclave a few miles east of the Palisades that is home to A-list celebrities such as Tom Brady, Travis Scott and LeBron James — the security checkpoint at the corner of Sunset Boulevard and Kenter Avenue, on the eastern edge of the evacuation zone, was especially tight Tuesday afternoon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany May, Muktita Suhartono and Claire Fu
title: Chinese Celebrities and Tourists Think Twice About Thailand
description: The brief abduction of a Chinese actor who was trafficked into Myanmar to work in a scam camp has rattled travelers from a country that Thailand relies on for tourism.
content: Chartered flights have been canceled. Performances have been called off or postponed. Tour agencies have fielded requests from travelers who want to change their plans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Late Night Seems to Think This Pete Hegseth Fellow Is Unqualified
description: Jordan Klepper said the former weekend show host’s only qualification to run the Pentagon was that “Trump liked watching him sit on a couch on Saturday mornings.”
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi
title: U.S. Sues Southwest Airlines Over Chronic Delays
description: The Transportation Department said in a lawsuit that two of the airline’s routes were consistently delayed in violation of federal rules.
content: The federal government sued Southwest Airlines on Wednesday, accusing the airline of harming passengers who flew on two routes that were plagued by consistent delays in 2022.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: I’m a Cyclist. Must I Wait for the Light When I Know I Can Safely Cross?
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on the intersection of courteousness and lawfulness on city streets.
content: I recently started using my bike as my main mode of transportation, and there are many intersections near my house that feature a pedestrian scramble (a.k.a. an exclusive pedestrian interval). When there are no pedestrians in the walkway but the signal remains on for them, I’m unsure whether I should go. On one hand, it would make my commute more efficient and probably safer (the risk of getting hit by a car is much lower). On the other hand, there’s a vanishingly small chance I hit a pedestrian and a much higher chance I undermine pedestrians’ confidence in their safety — if they see bikes crossing during the designated pedestrian time, they’ll feel less safe in the area in the future. Plus it’s technically illegal. What do you think? — Name Withheld
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Lane Scheppele and Norman Eisen
title: Are We Sleepwalking Into Autocracy?
description: What we can learn from countries that have pushed back on threats to democracy.
content: Since Donald Trump’s election victory, we have witnessed striking accommodations to his narrow win and mandate, what has been called “anticipatory obedience.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Theodore Schleifer and Mike Isaac
title: Zuckerberg Will Host a Party for Trump’s Inauguration
description: Mark Zuckerberg, the Meta chief executive, is one of several tech leaders expected to play a high-profile role in celebrating the new administration next week.
content: Mark Zuckerberg, the Meta chief executive who has tried to keep a distance from politics, is warming to President-elect Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: Deal Has Exposed Fissures in Netanyahu’s Right-Wing Government
description: One far-right minister, Itamar Ben-Gvir, claimed to have scuppered similar agreements over the past year. But, the prime minister has blamed Hamas for the failures.
content: Two days before Israel and Hamas reached a long-awaited cease-fire and hostage-release deal, Itamar Ben-Gvir, a rebellious far-right Israeli minister, issued a video statement calling on another far-right coalition partner to join forces and scupper the agreement by quitting Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s government.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Franz Lidz
title: She Made Things Better Down Where It’s Wetter
description: Julie Packard discusses highlights of her four decades with the Monterey Bay Aquarium, which she has led since it opened. She’s now stepping back from the role.
content: Julie Packard, the marine biologist who has presided over the Monterey Bay Aquarium since it opened in 1984 and shepherded it through the Covid pandemic, announced her retirement as executive director on Wednesday. Ms. Packard has helped repurpose the thick-glassed fish museums of old into potent forces for ocean conservation action.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ted Loos
title: Calder Gardens Names a Curatorial Leader and Sets September Opening
description: Juana Berrío, currently at the Whitney Independent Study Program, will be senior director of programs at the cultural center in Philadelphia.
content: Calder Gardens, the coming Philadelphia cultural project in a city that has seen few new major arts institutions recently, gets closer to being a reality this week with the announcement of its opening, set for September, and a central hire.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Schmall
title: Not Drunk, Not Dry: What it Means to Be ‘Soberish’
description: Conscious of the health risks of alcohol, more people are experimenting with cutting back on drinking.
content: One day last year, Christine Mosley woke up with the kind of hangover that inspires self-reckoning. That day, she decided she would never drink again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Josh Ocampo
title: Did You Lose Your Home in the California Fires? We Want to Hear From You.
description: The New York Times would like to help tell the stories of people who are facing this devastating reality by sharing photos and memories of what has been lost.
content: As of Wednesday morning, the wildfires in Southern California had destroyed thousands of homes and displaced more than 100,000 people, according to Los Angeles County officials, leaving many heartbroken residents with only memories of their beloved houses and apartments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: Russell Vought Poised to Expand Power of White House Budget Office
description: If confirmed, Mr. Vought will be at the center of President-elect Donald Trump’s plans to upend the federal bureaucracy.
content: While leading the Office of Management and Budget during the first Trump administration, Russell T. Vought took steps to expand the number of federal employees required to work during a government shutdown, froze military aid for Ukraine and railed against “wasteful spending” such as foreign aid and organizing unions in other nations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Becky Ferreira
title: Celtic Women Held Sway in ‘Matrilocal’ Societies
description: An ancient cemetery reveals a Celtic tribe that lived in England 2,000 years ago and that was organized around maternal lineages, according to a DNA analysis.
content: A tantalizing vision of a women-centric society has emerged from an ancient cemetery in the bucolic countryside of southwest England.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Coscarelli
title: Drake Sues His Label, Calling Kendrick Lamar’s ‘Not Like Us’ Defamatory
description: In a federal lawsuit on Wednesday, Drake accused Universal Music Group of putting his life and reputation at risk by releasing and promoting the popular diss track.
content: During a venomous back-and-forth barrage of diss tracks last year, the rappers Drake and Kendrick Lamar accused each other of phoniness, hypocrisy and abuse. But while fans anointed Lamar’s chart-topping single “Not Like Us” the battle’s knockout blow, Drake saw the song’s punchlines invoking pedophilia as something far more insidious — and with real-world consequences.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush, Devlin Barrett and Adam Goldman
title: Bondi, Expressing Loyalty to Trump, Vows No Political Inquiries
description: Pam Bondi cast herself as an independent prosecutor who would keep politics out of the Justice Department if confirmed as President Trump’s attorney general.
content: Pam Bondi, President-elect Donald J. Trump’s pick for attorney general, refused to explicitly say that she would defy Mr. Trump’s pressure during a confirmation hearing on Wednesday, but she offered a blanket promise that “politics will not play a part” in deciding who to investigate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: Gaza Cease-Fire Deal Brings Joy, but Is Shadowed With Uncertainty
description: An agreement offers Gazans at least some respite, and for Israelis it means the release of hostages. But the deal’s ambiguity leaves open the possibility that fighting could resume within weeks.
content: After 15 months of bombardment and suffering, the prospect of a cease-fire and a hostage release deal in Gaza provides Palestinians and Israelis with a glimmer of jubilation, but it’s a view tinged with uncertainty.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Taub
title: Satirical Singer Kinky Friedman’s Posthumous Surprise: A Sincere Album
description: On “Poet of Motel 6,” due March 21, the country musician known for shocking audiences grapples with death and his own legacy.
content: The music producer David Mansfield flew down to Austin in May 2023 to record with Kinky Friedman, the satirical country singer, mystery novelist and twice-failed candidate for Texas governor. “I don’t think he ever said this was going to be his swan song,” said Mansfield, a fiddler and guitarist who met Friedman in 1976, when they were both part of Bob Dylan’s Rolling Thunder Revue. The two just got to work on the follow-up to Friedman’s 2019 LP, “Resurrection.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farnaz Fassihi, Emma Bubola and Edward Wong
title: Musk Said to Have Intervened to Help Free Italian Jailed in Iran
description: The Italian journalist was released soon after Elon Musk met with an Iranian ambassador, officials in Iran said. So was an Iranian detained in Italy who was wanted by the U.S.
content: When an Italian journalist was arrested in Iran in December, her boyfriend back home feared she might linger in prison for years. So, amid talk that Iran and Italy were negotiating a prisoner swap that involved the United States, he says, he decided to try to get a message to someone who might be in a position to help.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: Cease-Fire Deal With Israel Comes as Hamas Is Severely Weakened
description: Israel’s 15-month bombardment of Gaza has destroyed much of Hamas’s military wing. It has also degraded the Iran-backed proxy network that helps sustain the militant group.
content: Hamas may claim victory after a cease-fire with Israel that was announced on Wednesday, but 15 months of war have left the militant group severely weakened.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: ‘Conclave’ and ‘Emilia Pérez’ Compete in Wide-Open BAFTAs Race
description: “Anora,” “A Compete Unknown” and “The Brutalist” are also in the running for best film at the British equivalent of the Oscars.
content: “Conclave,” Edward Berger’s thriller about the selection of a new pope, received the most nominations on Wednesday for this year’s EE British Academy Film Awards, known as the BAFTAs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Small
title: World Monuments Fund Puts Moon on List of At-Risk Sites
description: The organization said that more than 90 important sites on the moon could risk destruction if space tourism is left unregulated.
content: For years, the World Monuments Fund has sought to draw attention and resources to endangered cultural heritage sites including Machu Picchu in Peru, temples in Cambodia and the old city of Taiz in Yemen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raja Abdulrahim and Ivor Prickett
title: Many Syrians Want Justice for Regime Crimes. Others Want Revenge.
description: The new interim Syrian government says it will hunt down and punish senior security officials and others, but concern is growing about attacks on former low-level members of the Assad regime’s forces.
content: Bashar Abdo had just returned home last month after four years in the Syrian military when a mob of neighbors and others armed with guns and knives swarmed his family’s front door and accused him of being a thug for the ousted regime.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brad Plumer
title: Chris Wright, Trump’s Energy Pick, Is Quizzed on Climate and Clean Energy
description: Wright, the founder of a fracking firm, testified that he would back all forms of low-carbon energy as well as gas, oil and coal.
content: Chris Wright, President-elect Donald J. Trump’s pick for energy secretary, tried to reassure Democrats at his confirmation hearing on Wednesday that he believed climate change was a “global challenge that we need to solve” and that he would support the development of all forms of energy, including wind and solar power.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quote of the Day: Patchy Rules Let Police Use Tasers Freely
description: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, January 15, 2025.
content: “How do you hold someone accountable if you don’t know?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher and Reid J. Epstein
title: Faiz Shakir, Ex-Bernie Sanders Campaign Chief, Joins Race for D.N.C. Chair
description: Mr. Shakir said his mission, should he win the post, would be to redefine the Democratic Party as the party of the working class.
content: Faiz Shakir, a former campaign manager for Senator Bernie Sanders and a longtime progressive Democratic strategist, is jumping into the race for chairman of the Democratic National Committee, demanding the party more directly debate how to position itself to rebuild public trust and regain power.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yotam Ottolenghi
title: The Secret to Perfect Veggie Meatballs Is Imperfection
description: I am not saying that anything goes. But with some creativity and a bit of trial and error, you will find that more goes than you would think.
content: The name, Ultimate Veggie Meatballs, was given to this recipe before it was created. It was still a vision, really, an intention to give the cook some comfort once the virtuousness that follows the holidays — broths, slaws and general avoidance of all the things we actually desire — had run its course. It anticipated the inevitability of our clawing back resolutions, losing the clarity we thought we had about what we want to eat, what kind of life we want to lead or who we want to be in 2025.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan and Caroline Tompkins
title: Guy Pearce Never Needed to Be a Movie Star
description: After roles in “Memento” and “L.A. Confidential” made him famous, Pearce turned his back on Hollywood. At age 57, he’s returned in “The Brutalist.”
content: A few years ago, as Guy Pearce filmed a television series in his native Australia, a young actress introduced herself by asking who his American agents were. She was determined to succeed in Hollywood, as she felt he had, and was eager to seek a shortcut.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lydia DePillis
title: Economic Toll of Los Angeles Fires Goes Far Beyond Destroyed Homes
description: The ongoing disaster will affect residents’ health, local industries, public budgets and the cost of housing for years to come.
content: After decades of mounting damage from climate-fueled natural disasters, researchers have compiled many misery-filled data sets that trace the economic fallout over weeks, months and years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: The Israeli Right May Soon Be Disenchanted With Trump
description: The president-elect may have the soul of a bully, but he also has the instincts of a dealmaker.
content: The most interesting detail of the hostage and cease-fire deal that Israeli and Hamas officials agreed to on Wednesday lies neither in its terms, which mainly resemble what’s been on the table for months, nor in the fact that Benjamin Netanyahu, Israel’s prime minister, is effectively acquiescing to Hamas’s continued grip on power in the Gaza Strip after loudly and repeatedly vowing he wouldn’t.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Ruberg
title: U.S. Won’t Bring Charges Against Officers in Death of Ronald Greene
description: Investigators found insufficient evidence to federally charge the surviving officers in the encounter, in which a Black driver was pulled over, dragged, beaten and shocked.
content: The Justice Department will not bring criminal charges in the 2019 death of Ronald Greene, a Black driver who was pulled over and beaten by the police in Louisiana, officials said Tuesday, bringing an end to a yearslong federal criminal investigation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: A Bakery, a Landlord and a Heated Fight About Back Rent
description: The Silver Moon Bakery on the Upper West Side is embroiled in a legal dispute. Loyal customers are worried about its fate.
content: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. Today we’ll look at a landlord’s lawsuit against a beloved bakery on the Upper West Side. We’ll also get details on the “affordability agenda” that Gov. Kathy Hochul outlined in her State of the State address.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liam Stack
title: Sheriff’s Deputies Handcuff Girl, 11, After Mistaking Her for Suspect
description: Deputies in Syracuse, N.Y., detained the girl, who is Black, for several minutes after mistakenly identifying her as a suspect in a car theft. Video of the episode drew fierce criticism.
content: The Onondaga County Sheriff’s Office in New York said on Tuesday that it would change its policy regarding detained children after a video shared widely online showed deputies handcuffing an 11-year-old girl the day before.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. D. Biersdorfer
title: How to Download Your Videos and Other Data From TikTok
description: With a TikTok ban looming in the United States and the app’s future unknown, now might be a good time to save your work while you can.
content: Feeling the sudden need to save your TikTok videos in case the site abruptly goes away? Here are a few methods for nontechnical users who want copies of the videos they personally uploaded or made on TikTok. You can also download a copy of your TikTok data right from your account, which doesn’t get you the video files themselves but will give other items including your direct messages and followers list.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Hunt
title: Luigi Mangione Isn’t the First Accused Killer America Has Loved. He Won’t Be the Last.
description: The mythology of a dashing foe recast as a symbol of resistance has taken on new momentum through social media.
content: My father gave me the middle name James — not because it was his own middle name, but because of his affection for an outlaw who died roughly a century before I was born. Jesse Woodson James was a prolific bank and train robber who was shot to death by a fellow gang member in 1882. In the years that followed he would become a uniquely American sort of celebrity: an unrepentant serial killer and Confederate guerrilla whose exploits were nonetheless memorialized in a folk song that recast his crimes as acts of resistance. “Jesse was a man, a friend to the poor/He’d never see a man suffer pain,” ran one version. “And with his brother Frank, he robbed the Chicago bank/And stopped the Glendale train.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Brooks
title: We Deserve Pete Hegseth
description: If you thought the former TV host would be asked important questions at the confirmation hearings this week, you must be living under the illusion that we live in a serious country.
content: First let me hit you with some realities:
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘You Have to Let Your Gut Lead’
description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
content: The word “love” was not in his vocabulary. Hugs made him tense. He was critical of his children, but bragged about us to others. Near the end, I sat in his hospital room, working while he slept. I looked up to find him gazing at me, misty-eyed. “I really like you,” he said, struggling to speak and breathe. I laughed, then cried, realizing I would never hear the words I had been waiting for. Only much later did I understand that I had. — Gila Silverman
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck
title: Defending Michigan’s Auto Industry, Whitmer Warns of Tariff Risks
description: Gov. Gretchen Whitmer addressed the Detroit Auto Show, saying that tariffs should not be used “to punish our closest trading partners,” like Canada.
content: Gov. Gretchen Whitmer of Michigan, a leading Democrat from a critical battleground state, on Wednesday subtly warned against President-elect Donald J. Trump’s tariff threats targeting Canada, even as she stressed her broader willingness to work with him on the cusp of his second inauguration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut, Daria Mitiuk and Finbarr O'Reilly
title: Inside Ukraine’s Last Stand at a Vital Coal Mine
description: The mine, near the frontline city of Pokrovsk, produced coking coal crucial for Ukraine’s steel industry. It kept running until the very last moment, when Russian forces finally reached its gates.
content: It was late at night and Anton Telegin was driving toward a sprawling coal mine near Ukraine’s eastern front line, using darkness to evade Russian attack drones.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Arango
title: L.A. Prosecutor Vows Severe Penalties for Looting and Price Gouging
description: The recently elected district attorney of Los Angeles, Nathan Hochman, signals that crime fighting will be key to the region’s resurgence from the devastating wildfires.
content: Law enforcement officials have issued a message to anyone thinking of looting, engaging in price gouging, pursuing internet scams in the wildfire evacuation zones around Los Angeles or committing arson anywhere: Don’t.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Misogynistic Taunts Cost Philadelphia Eagles Fan His Job at D.E.I. Firm
description: The fan, who was caught on video harassing a female Packers fan at Sunday’s playoff game, was also barred from future events at Lincoln Financial Field.
content: A Philadelphia Eagles fan who spewed crude insults at a woman rooting for the visiting Green Bay Packers during Sunday’s wild-card playoff game lost his job this week at a New Jersey company that specializes in D.E.I. work because of his conduct, which was caught on a viral video.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Wang
title: What China Wants in Panama: More Trade, Projects and Influence
description: Beijing’s efforts to expand its reach in the country have hit several obstacles, in part because of American pressure.
content: There was talk of a high-speed rail line that China would build in Panama. A new subway line in Panama City. A modern container port.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Mott and Vishakha Darbha
title: The Home Insurance L.A. — and America — Needs
description: In an era of climate catastrophe, the government must take action to save home insurance — and homeownership.
content: The Los Angeles wildfires offer a stark reminder that we no longer live in an era of reliable home insurance. An exodus of insurance companies from disaster-prone areas has put the American dream of homeownership in peril. In this episode, the climate reporter Nick Mott makes the case for a national climate catastrophe insurance plan that could help protect families from the devastating losses being experienced in California.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman
title: Why Trump Wanted a Mideast Cease-Fire Deal Before Taking Office
description: The agreement removed one of the most vexing international conflicts that hovered over the start of his second term.
content: For President-elect Donald J. Trump, the Israeli-Gaza cease-fire deal was key for two reasons.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: You’ll Never Guess Who Trump’s New Favorite President Is
description: What does the president-elect actually mean when he talks about making America great again?
content: For nearly 10 years Donald Trump has promised to Make America Great Again, and for nearly 10 years the former and soon-to-be president has declined to specify when, exactly, America was great.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Eric Schmitt, Rob Szypko, Rachelle Bonja, Carlos Prieto, MJ Davis Lin, Maria Byrne, Dan Powell and Alyssa Moxley
title: Drunkenness, Women and Wokeness: A Dramatic Confirmation Hearing for Pete Hegseth
description: Highlights from the first big day of hearings on the Trump cabinet, and what comes next.
content: This week, the confirmation process for President-elect Donald J. Trump’s cabinet picks kicked off with his most contentious nominee, Pete Hegseth, for the position of defense secretary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. D. Biersdorfer
title: How to Create a Multimedia Digital Journal of Your Life
description: People have been keeping personal diaries for several millenniums, but free smartphone apps now let you capture much more than words.
content: Still looking for a New Year’s resolution for self-improvement? Consider keeping a journal, which studies have shown might help with one’s mental well-being and anxiety issues, while also providing a creative outlet for personal expression.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Schwirtz
title: Poland’s Leader Suggests Russian Hand in Plot to Attack Western Cargo Planes
description: “I can only confirm that Russia planned acts of air terror, not just against Poland but against airlines across the globe,” said Poland’s prime minister, Donald Tusk.
content: Poland’s prime minister appeared on Wednesday to confirm the conclusions of Western intelligence officials who had warned of a Russian plot to blow up cargo aircraft over Western countries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zeynep Tufekci
title: Zuckerberg’s Macho Posturing Looks a Lot Like Cowardice
description: Focus on what the Meta chief does, not what he says.
content: I really, really wanted to like Mark Zuckerberg’s gushing appearance on Joe Rogan’s podcast last Friday. Zuckerberg, the chief executive of Meta, Facebook’s parent company, made some important points about the inadequacies of fact-checking as well as the troubling ways that governments can manipulate private companies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Philip Galanes
title: Our Only Friends Went Away for the Weekend Without Us. We’re Hurt!
description: Adjusting to life in a new city, a couple was stung to learn that the only people they know in town, the husband’s childhood friends, didn’t invite them on a recent getaway.
content: My husband and I moved recently from a big city to his hometown. The only friends we have here are his two best friends from childhood, with whom he has remained close in the decade since he moved away, and their significant others. This weekend, we saw on Instagram that both couples posted photos from a fun weekend trip they took as a foursome. My husband was very hurt that he was not invited, and I was offended, too. We will be celebrating one of their birthdays next weekend, and I want to tell them that we would have loved to come along on their weekend trip. My husband thinks that would be obtuse. Your thoughts?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Goldstein
title: Jeffrey Epstein’s Associates Could Reap Benefit of a Big Tax Refund
description: The estate’s assets have swelled to $145 million, a probate court filing in the U.S. Virgin Islands shows. Much of that won’t make its way to Mr. Epstein’s victims.
content: Jeffrey Epstein’s once vast estate — art, jewelry, lavish properties and investments — was meant to be drained by settlements to his many sexual abuse victims and payments to resolve other legal claims. But now it appears that two of his most loyal business associates, who are serving as executors of his estate, stand in line to potentially reap a big benefit.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Jan. 15, 2025
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, Jan. 15, 2025.
content: An article on Sunday about Susie Wiles, President-elect Donald J. Trump’s incoming White House chief of staff misstated the title of an official Elon Musk met with in November. The meeting was with Iran’s ambassador to the United Nations, not Iran’s ambassador to the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff
title: Canada Readies Billions of Dollars in Retaliatory Moves to Trump Tariff Threat
description: The government is preparing for the possibility that the incoming U.S. administration will impose high tariffs on Canadian goods, setting the close allies up for a showdown.
content: The Canadian government is preparing billions of dollars in retaliatory measures on U.S. exports to Canada if President-elect Donald J. Trump makes good on a threat to impose tariffs on Canadian goods, setting up a potential showdown between two countries that are each other’s largest trading partners.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffery C. Mays
title: After Indictment, Eric Adams Collects $250,000 From Donors
description: Mr. Adams, who is facing a federal corruption indictment and was denied public matching funds, said his totals show “my base of support is still there.”
content: After Mayor Eric Adams was indicted on federal corruption charges last year, his campaign donations dried up. The mayor, a prolific fund-raiser, received only $250 during the last recording period after his indictment became public.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Egan and Alexandra Alter
title: Neil Gaiman Responds to Explosive Report of Sexual Assault
description: “I have never engaged in nonconsensual sexual activity with anyone,” said the best-selling author in response to allegations in New York magazine.
content: On Tuesday, the best-selling author Neil Gaiman denied allegations of sexual abuse and assault made against him by multiple women and reported in an explosive New York magazine article this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiroko Tabuchi
title: Even Homes That Evade the Fire Face Toxic Ash Risk, Studies Show
description: Health hazards from soot and smoke blown indoors onto furniture and walls can linger for months: “Wind will get through every crack.”
content: Armed with two garden hoses hooked up to a sputtering tap, Matthew Craig battled fire and smoke to save his house from the onslaught of flames that devastated much of Altadena, a once leafy corner of Los Angeles County. The wind felt like dragon’s breath, he said, and “we were all eating smoke.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Judson Jones and Amy Graff
title: Tuesday’s Winds Didn’t Reach Their Predicted Speeds, but Wednesday’s Might
description: On Tuesday afternoon, forecasters at the National Weather Service dropped their most severe warnings for the rest of the day. But the alerts will be back in place early Wednesday.
content: Meteorologists get it wrong sometimes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edward Wong, Michael Crowley and Karoun Demirjian
title: Takeaways From Marco Rubio’s Senate Hearing
description: Mr. Rubio expressed views aligned with those of most senators who work on foreign policy, while taking care not to break from Donald J. Trump’s unorthodox ideas.
content: Marco Rubio, the Republican senator from Florida named by Donald J. Trump to be the next secretary of state, was warmly welcomed by senators from both parties at his confirmation hearing on Wednesday. He has served for years on the Foreign Relations and Intelligence Committees in the Senate, and is known as a lawmaker devoted to the details of foreign policy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Gavin Newsom Criticizes Republicans for ‘Politicizing’ California Wildfires
description: The governor lashed back after several Republican leaders said that aid to his state as it deals with deadly wildfires should be conditional.
content: Gov. Gavin Newsom responded on Tuesday to Republicans who said federal aid provided to California for the wildfire response should be conditional and require policy changes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: Firefighting Pilots Face High-Pressure Job: ‘It Gets a Bit Scary’
description: The people flying planes and tankers involved in dousing blazes face hot, sweaty, turbulent conditions — and the risk that fire retardant won’t land where it’s needed.
content: Firefighting aircraft have been unleashing tens of thousands of gallons of water and bright-pink fire retardant on the wildfires ripping through Los Angeles over the past week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Biden’s Presidential Legacy: An Era of Change, Forever Marked by Trump
description: Biden’s disastrous debate performance highlighted age concerns.
content: President Biden ran for the White House promising to be a transitional figure, then once he got there began thinking of himself as a transformational one. But after a tumultuous four years in office, it turns out he was really neither.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cassandra Vinograd
title: Missile Attack Prompts Emergency Power Cuts in Ukraine
description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine said air defenses had shot down at least 30 missiles from a “massive” barrage that had targeted gas and energy facilities.
content: Ukraine said Russian forces had unleashed a “massive” missile attack on the country’s infrastructure on Wednesday, forcing officials to impose emergency power cuts to relieve pressure on the country’s battered grid.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ephrat Livni
title: Gaza Hostage Deal Could Come as Trump Takes Office, in Echoes of 1981
description: Dozens of American hostages held at the U.S. Embassy in Tehran for more than a year were freed just as Ronald Reagan was inaugurated.
content: A deal to free Israeli hostages in exchange for Palestinian prisoners could be finalized days before President Donald J. Trump’s inauguration. The scenario is reminiscent of 1981, when American hostages held at the U.S. Embassy in Tehran for more than a year were freed just as Ronald Reagan became commander in chief.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William K. Reilly
title: The Catholic Church Must Challenge Trump on Deportations
description: Its voice has been largely absent in the national conversation.
content: Among Donald Trump’s most alarming, repeated and ambitious commitments as a candidate was to arrest and deport up to 12 million undocumented immigrants. Many are Mexican and have been in the United States for more than 10 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Lubell
title: The Design Legacy of Los Angeles That Fell to the Fires
description: The finality of the wildfires’ destruction has taken 10 more cherished buildings — by Richard Neutra, Gregory Ain, Eric Owen Moss and others.
content: More than a week after Los Angeles’s devastating fires began, the losses to the region’s rich architectural legacy are becoming clearer. The fires have already destroyed more of the county’s built heritage than other single event, according to Adrian Scott Fine, president and chief executive of the Los Angeles Conservancy, which recorded the loss of more than 30 significant structures on its website. That number is growing by the hour as officials, building owners and others make their way into the disaster zones to assess the damage.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Pete Hegseth’s ‘Deeply Troubling’ Selection
description: Readers say he lacks the qualifications and integrity to be defense secretary. Also: Heroism amid the tragedy in L.A.; alone in an empty church.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ellen Barry
title: Online Therapy Boom Has Mainly Benefited Privileged Groups, Studies Find
description: Digital mental health platforms were supposed to expand access for the neediest patients. Researchers say that hasn’t happened.
content: The number of Americans receiving psychotherapy increased by 30 percent during the pandemic, as virtual sessions replaced in-person appointments — but new research dampens the hope that technology will make mental health care more available to the neediest populations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Religious Ceremonies
description: Do you belong to a religious or spiritual community? What traditions and rituals are important to you and your faith?
content: Tens of millions of Hindus are convening this week in what is expected to be the world’s largest human gathering. About 400 million Hindu pilgrims from around the globe will bathe in and around the Ganges River over the next six weeks for the Maha Kumbh Mela, a religious festival that happens every 12 years in the northern Indian city of Prayagraj.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Wednesday Briefing
description: Optimism about Gaza cease-fire talks.
content: Israel and Hamas are close to a deal on a cease-fire in Gaza and the release of hostages there, Antony Blinken, the U.S. secretary of state, said yesterday. “It’s closer than it’s ever been before,” he said. “But right now as we sit here we await final word from Hamas on its acceptance. And until we get that word, we’ll remain on the brink.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Biden Races to Cement His Legacy Through a Series of Actions
description: The president has issued policy decisions in a number of areas in the final days of his term, including environmental justice, prison reform and immigration.
content: In the final days of his term, President Biden has issued a series of policy decisions intended to cement his agenda and, in some cases, make it harder for President-elect Donald J. Trump to put in place his own.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Martin, Reva Goldberg, Emily Lang, Davis Land, Christina Djossa, Amy Pearl, Jen Poyant, Lynn Levy, Daniel Ramirez, Dan Powell, Aman Sahota, Rowan Niemisto, Diane Wong and Pat McCusker
title: Hank Azaria’s Advice for Overcoming Codependency
description: After his divorce devastated him, Azaria, a well-known voice actor, “dated himself” for a year.
content: Hank Azaria is used to putting on other personalities. You probably know him best from his work as a voice actor on “The Simpsons,” where he plays Moe the bartender, Professor Frink, Chief Wiggum and Snake Jailbird, among many others. His list of credits in stage plays, movies and TV shows is prolific, including roles like his Tony-nominated performance in “Spamalot,” Phoebe’s boyfriend on “Friends” and the dog walker on “Mad About You.” But at a certain point in his life, Azaria realized that he was using humor and acting to be anyone but himself, and that it was affecting his real-life relationships. After five devastating heartbreaks, he resolved to look inward, address his codependency issues and become his most authentic self.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Proenza Schouler Designers Depart in Further Fashion World Tumult
description: After a year of major creative change, a new round of musical chairs has begun.
content: The very messy game of designer musical chairs that roiled the fashion world at the end of 2024 is continuing into 2025.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Wordle Review No. 1,307
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Thursday, Jan. 16, 2025.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kashmir Hill
title: She Is in Love With ChatGPT
description: A 28-year-old woman with a busy social life spends hours on end talking to her A.I. boyfriend for advice and consolation. And yes, they do have sex.
content: Ayrin’s love affair with her A.I. boyfriend started last summer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Traub
title: Bill McCartney, Coach Who Led a Movement for ‘Godly’ Men, Dies at 84
description: After transforming the University of Colorado’s football team, he founded the Promise Keepers, a masculine revivalist group that drew millions of supporters.
content: Bill McCartney, a football coach who in the 1980s took the University of Colorado from perennial losers to national champions, but who later left behind his $350,000 annual salary to refashion his locker-room message about prayer and sacrifice into a sprawling men’s evangelical movement, died on Friday in Boulder, Colo. He was 84.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mullin
title: Washington Post Employees Plead for a Summit With Jeff Bezos
description: In a letter, more than 400 employees asked Mr. Bezos, the company’s owner, to meet, saying they were “deeply alarmed” by recent decisions at the paper.
content: Hundreds of employees at The Washington Post sent a letter to Jeff Bezos on Tuesday evening, asking the Amazon founder for a meeting amid widespread concern about the future of the newspaper.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum
title: What to Know About Covid Right Now
description: Experts expect cases to rise again this winter. Here’s the latest on symptoms, treatments and testing.
content: There are few constants when it comes to Covid, but one thing has held true over the years: Cases climb in the winter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Bearak
title: Are Biden and Trump at Odds on Global Energy Strategy? Maybe Not So Much.
description: When it comes to gas exports and competition with China, the two administrations share a similar vision, the top U.S. energy diplomat says.
content: At their confirmation hearings on Wednesday, the two men in line to oversee the United States’ global energy policies, Senator Marco Rubio and the fossil fuel executive Chris Wright, are expected to assail President Biden as overly concerned with climate change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi, busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. Enter the comments section to see hints, conversation, helpful tips and creative content from other solvers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Rasgon
title: Here’s What the Provisional Cease-Fire Deal Says
description: In the first phase, 33 hostages and hundreds of Palestinian prisoners would be freed, and hundreds of trucks with humanitarian aid would be allowed into Gaza daily, a copy of the agreement says.
content: The provisional cease-fire deal announced on Wednesday between Israel and Hamas would begin with an initial phase lasting six weeks, involve the release of 33 hostages and hundreds of Palestinian prisoners and allow the entry of 600 trucks carrying humanitarian relief daily, according to a copy of the agreement obtained by The New York Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer and Hurubie Meko
title: N.Y.P.D. Bans High-Speed Chases for Low-Level Offenses
description: A quarter of the nearly 2,300 vehicle pursuits last year led to crashes, property damage or physical harm, the police said. Most chases will no longer be allowed.
content: New York City police officers will no longer engage in high-speed chases of drivers who break traffic laws or commit other low-level offenses, the Police Department said, in an effort to stop the crashes that have led to serious injuries and deaths in America’s most densely populated major city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Jewett
title: White House Advances Last-Minute Push to Cut Nicotine in Cigarettes
description: In the final days of the Biden administration, the F.D.A. is moving ahead with a proposal to require companies to produce a less addictive product for traditional smokers.
content: The Biden administration unveiled a proposal on Wednesday to cut the level of nicotine in cigarettes, a last-minute push on a plan that could meaningfully cut cancer rates nationwide and extend the lives of millions of cigarette smokers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: Whisper Network Emerges in the Desperate Rush for Housing in L.A.
description: In a market with few homes available, real estate agents are searching for the ones no one knows about.
content: As Los Angeles residents fled their homes last week, a luxury real estate broker started compiling a list of all the homeowners he knew with empty second or third homes in Los Angeles and asking them to rent them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sapna Maheshwari
title: TikTok Says Employees Will Have Jobs Even if Ban Takes Effect
description: The company is awaiting a decision over the constitutionality of a new law that aims to force a sale of the app to a non-Chinese owner under the threat of a ban.
content: TikTok sought to assure its U.S. employees on Tuesday that they will still have jobs next week even if the Supreme Court upholds a law that would see the video app banned in the United States on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Pogrebin
title: Arts Groups and Donors Create Fire Relief Fund for Los Angeles Artists
description: The fund, already at $12 million, is led by the Getty and includes major museums, foundations and philanthropists.
content: Major museums like the Getty and the Los Angeles County Museum of Art, along with philanthropists like Sheikha Al Mayassa bint Hamad bin Khalifa Al Thani of Qatar and foundations like Steven Spielberg’s, have raised $12 million for a fund to support the artists affected by the California wildfires.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger and Michael D. Shear
title: How the Cease-Fire Push Brought Together Biden and Trump’s Teams
description: Rarely have representatives of current and new presidents of different parties worked together at such a high-stakes moment. But the president and the president-elect didn’t quite share credit.
content: When President-elect Donald J. Trump’s Middle East envoy, Steve Witkoff, met with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel on Saturday to pressure him on a cease-fire deal in Gaza, there was someone on the speakerphone: Brett H. McGurk, President Biden’s longtime Mideast negotiator.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Conor Dougherty
title: A Sense of Belonging, Shaped by Fire
description: Conor Dougherty, who covers housing based in Los Angeles, explores the notion of where he’s from in the aftermath of the wildfires.
content: The built-in bookshelves in my Studio City house have two rows dedicated to works about California, three if you count a California fiction section that’s mostly L.A. noir. As a native Californian and Golden State history buff now raising two children in Los Angeles, I’ve read probably two million words about the goings-on of this city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Why Biden May Matter
description: We explore the president’s legacy.
content: One-term presidents don’t usually leave big legacies on domestic policy. If anything, political parties move away from the ideas of presidents who fail to win a second term. It was true of Gerald Ford, Jimmy Carter and George H.W. Bush.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced and Lauren Hirsch
title: Mister C.E.O. Goes to Washington
description: Billionaire business leaders, including Mark Zuckerberg, Jeff Bezos and Elon Musk, plan to make prominent appearances at Donald Trump’s inauguration next week.
content: Corporate America had already raced to donate big sums to Donald Trump’s record-breaking inaugural fund. Now some of its leaders appear eager to jockey for prominent positions at the inauguration next week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Gig Makeup?
description: Parker Higgins did this to us on purpose.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: Freedom From Harassment and Exploitation on Social Media, but Not for Girls
description: On “Girls Gone Wild,” Meta’s moderation changes and the permanence of online cruelty.
content: In a new documentary about “Girls Gone Wild” — a franchise that consisted of VHS tapes and DVDs of girl-next-door types exposing themselves and participating in pornographic scenes — several of the women who were featured as teenagers come forward. Now in their 30s and 40s, they say they were coerced into being filmed or were too drunk to consent. They talk about the trauma and harassment they continue to experience.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Fitzgerald
title: Three Men and a Rabbi Face a Life-Changing Test: A Toddler
description: Tom Lamont’s debut novel, “Going Home,” considers the joys and frustrations of raising a child who is not your own.
content: Tom Lamont’s “Going Home” is an exceptionally touching novel in multiple ways. It’s a story of fathers and sons. Male friendship and all its many — and not often discussed — complications. Jewish community, culture and faith. What goes into raising a young boy, and tending to loved ones who are at the end of their days. The cruel trick the universe plays that brings us from child to adult to child again over the course of our lives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Seems Ready to Back Texas Law Limiting Access to Pornography
description: The law, meant to shield minors from sexual materials on the internet by requiring adults to prove they are 18, was challenged on First Amendment grounds.
content: Several members of the Supreme Court’s conservative majority seemed deeply skeptical of a challenge to a Texas law that seeks to limit minors’ access to pornography, peppering a lawyer for the challengers with exceptionally hostile questions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser and Max Whittaker
title: Mexican Firefighters Watch for Hot Spots From the Palisades Fire
description: The firefighters were part of the first international team to join the effort to contain the Los Angeles-area blazes.
content: There was not a flame in sight when a team of firefighters, newly arrived from Mexico, set out on Tuesday to search through the brush-covered land above the Pacific Palisades neighborhood of Los Angeles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes
title: John Ratcliffe Lays Out a Vision for a More Aggressive C.I.A.
description: Donald Trump’s pick for the agency’s director seems likely to win some Democratic support for this nomination, but how much is unclear.
content: John Ratcliffe, President-elect Donald J. Trump’s pick for C.I.A. director, offered his vision for a more aggressive spy agency as he faced questions from senators on Wednesday about his decisions to declassify intelligence and ability to deliver unvarnished assessments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning and Amy Graff
title: In Parts of Los Angeles, Life Carries On but Is Hardly Normal
description: While many Angelenos have been devastated by the fires, others in the sprawling city have had to balance helping out with “normal life.”
content: Angelenos have spent the past week under a haze of smoke, barraged by evacuation warnings, many of them searching for a place to stay after fleeing their homes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Lipton
title: Albania Gives Jared Kushner Hotel Project a Nod as Trump Returns
description: The project is one of several that family members of President-elect Donald J. Trump have with foreign countries that have pending policy matters with the United States.
content: The government of Albania has given preliminary approval to a plan proposed by Jared Kushner, Donald J. Trump’s son-in-law, to build a $1.4 billion luxury hotel complex on a small abandoned military base off the coast of Albania.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Modern Love Podcast Team
title: Tell Us: When Did You Know You Were Falling in Love?
description: We may include your story in an episode of the “Modern Love” podcast.
content: Falling in love can be a magical experience, a sudden one, an utter mystery that at the same time makes perfect sense. Sometimes, it happens all at once. Other times, it’s a process. Regardless of how you fell in love, the “Modern Love” podcast wants to hear your story.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacob Gallagher
title: What Is Ye Trying to Tell Us Now?
description: His new clothing collection has words and letters in a foreign language, the message of which is unclear. But people are buying it.
content: When Ye speaks, his fans listen. Even if they have no idea what the heck he’s saying.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Szalai
title: The Secret to a Good Life? Thinking Like Socrates.
description: In “Open Socrates,” the scholar Agnes Callard argues that the ancient Greek philosopher offers a blueprint for an ethical life.
content: Maybe this is the year that you have resolved to drink less and exercise more. Or maybe you want to be kinder, gentler and more caring to the people around you.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: These Sheet-Pan Noodles Have Very Little Cleanup
description: Eric Kim cleverly cooks and assembles his japchae on a single sheet pan in this fast and fortifying dinner.
content: Of all the many reasons to love your sheet pans (and you know how much I love mine), perhaps their greatest feature is their talent for browning. You name it — vegetables, chicken, fish, chickpeas or tofu cubes — if it needs crisping or caramelization, roasting it on a trusty sheet pan is almost always easier, tidier and more consistent than searing it in a skillet on top of the stove.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Schuessler
title: Lorne Michaels Archive Going to the University of Texas
description: Michaels, the creator of “Saturday Night Live,” has donated his papers to the university’s Harry Ransom Center.
content: The archives of the man behind the tagline “Live From New York” are on their way to Texas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracy Mumford, Christina Morales, Choe Sang-Hun, Ian Stewart and Jessica Metzger
title: Gaza Cease-Fire ‘Right on the Brink,’ and the S.E.C. Sues Elon Musk
description: Plus, who gets a quinceañera?
content: On Today’s Episode:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: ‘Wicked,’ ‘Anora’ and ‘A Complete Unknown’ Get Writers Guild Nominations
description: The three films have momentum leading up to the planned Oscars nomination announcement next week.
content: The Writers Guild of America announced its feature-film nominations on Wednesday, furthering the awards-season momentum enjoyed by “Anora,” “Wicked” and “A Complete Unknown.” The announcement was delayed a week because of continuing wildfires in Los Angeles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Kolata
title: Cancer Remission Like Catherine’s Does Not Always Mean the Illness Is Cured
description: While the announcement is good news for the Princess of Wales, cancer experts describe the challenges of a life shadowed by an earlier diagnosis.
content: Princess Catherine, wife of Prince William, reported on Tuesday that her cancer was in remission. But what does it mean to be in remission from cancer?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Eligon and Tavares Cebola
title: ‘Burn Mozambique’: New President Takes Power in a Nation on Edge
description: Daniel Chapo was sworn in at a time of widespread anger directed at his party, Frelimo, which has led the country for 50 years and was accused of rigging the election.
content: Decades ago, Mozambique’s liberation party, Frelimo, easily attracted adoring crowds. The promise of salvation from Portuguese colonizers, and a life with jobs and housing for all, was an easy sell in a southern African nation that was suffering under racist rule.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmett Lindner
title: Thursday Briefing: A Gaza Cease-Fire Deal
description: Plus, ancient Celtic gender roles.
content: Negotiators from Israel and Hamas agreed yesterday to a 42-day cease-fire and hostage release in Gaza, President Biden and other officials announced. The deal would take effect on Sunday, the Qatari prime minister said. Officials in Israel and Qatar said both sides were still hammering out the final details, and Israel’s cabinet and government would still need to ratify it. Here’s the latest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley
title: Rubio Is in Spotlight on Second Big Day of Cabinet Hearings
description: Senator Marco Rubio, who is nominated for secretary of state, has a long history of personal and policy differences with President-elect Donald Trump.
content: Follow our live coverage of Marco Rubio’s Senate confirmation hearing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edward Wong and Hamed Aleaziz
title: Tackling Trump’s Policy in the Americas, Rubio Would Confront New Tensions
description: As the country’s top diplomat, Senator Marco Rubio of Florida, who has a special interest in Latin America, would be tasked with navigating Donald Trump’s efforts to expand U.S. influence.
content: Senator Marco Rubio, the son of Cuban immigrants, has a special interest in Latin America. So does President-elect Donald J. Trump, who has been laying out plans to expand U.S. influence — and territorial control — across the Americas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion No. 585
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Thursday, Jan. 16, 2025.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sadie Stein
title: Gay Talese Keeps Notes, Especially on Everyone’s Clothes
description: In a new collection about New York City, the writer turns his gimlet eye on its icons, its architecture, its hot spots — and its suits. “Clothes matter — especially when you get old,” he says.
content: “New York is a city of things unnoticed,” begins the essay that opens “A Town Without Time,” a new collection of Gay Talese’s New York writings. Talese then proceeds to list, with deceptive economy, the things he has noticed: chestnut vendors, pigeons, doormen, copy boys, ants.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Flavelle
title: How to Get FEMA Help
description: The agency offers different types of financial assistance after disasters. The fastest is a one-time payment of $770.
content: After disasters like the Los Angeles wildfires, the Federal Emergency Management Agency offers different types of financial assistance. The fastest is what FEMA calls “serious needs assistance,” which is a one-time payment of $770. That money is meant to be used for immediate needs, such as food or other supplies, for people who had to leave their homes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Wesley Morris, Linda Villarosa, Elyssa Dudley, Wendy Dorr, Paula Szuchman and Sophia Lanman
title: Relax? Don’t Do It.
description: Wesley Morris on the culture that keeps chemical hair relaxers on shelves.
content: Last year, when our critic Wesley Morris read Linda Villarosa’s reporting on the dangers of chemical hair relaxers, he was reminded of the many times he watched his sister painfully endure the process of having her hair straightened. He wondered, “Why do we do this to ourselves? Why does hair mean so much?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rob Copeland and Danielle Kaye
title: It’s a Good (Great?) Time to Be a Big Bank
description: The largest banks, including JPMorgan Chase, Wells Fargo and Goldman Sachs, reported bumper profits on Wednesday.
content: Worried about the economy? You must not run a major bank.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives and Conor Dougherty
title: California Officials Seek to Stem Property Speculation and Evictions During Fires
description: Californians are worried that the blazes, which have damaged thousands of homes, will make the city’s housing crisis worse.
content: Gov. Gavin Newsom of California and members of the Los Angeles City Council took steps to prevent property speculation and evictions, as concerns grow that the devastating wildfires will make the city’s housing shortage worse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David A. Fahrenthold
title: Nonprofit Founded by Stacey Abrams Admits Secretly Aiding Her 2018 Campaign
description: The New Georgia Project, whose leaders also included Raphael Warnock, now a senator, admitted violating campaign finance laws. It agreed to a $300,000 penalty.
content: A nonprofit founded by Stacey Abrams, a Georgia Democrat, admitted on Wednesday that it had violated state law by concealing the fact that it had campaigned for her during her 2018 run for governor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Jacobs and Teddy Rosenbluth
title: F.D.A. Bans Red Dye 3 in Foods, Linking It to Cancer in Rats
description: Consumer and food safety groups have long urged the agency to revoke the use of this dye and others. The F.D.A. says studies have shown that it causes cancer in rats, but not in humans.
content: The Food and Drug Administration on Wednesday banned the use of Red Dye No. 3 in food, beverages and drugs, more than three decades after the synthetic coloring was first found to cause cancer in male laboratory rats.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Abi-Habib and Alejandro Cegarra
title: Panama Wants to Preserve U.S. Alliance, but Trump Could Push It Closer to China
description: President-elect Donald J. Trump’s threat to take back the Panama Canal may be posturing, but it could dampen the Panamanian government’s wish to broaden relations with the United States, analysts say.
content: As Panama’s president laid a wreath to honor those who died protesting the American occupation 60 years ago, the ceremony attendees were resolute.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Chung
title: Overbooked Flight? What You Can Do if an Airline Bumps You.
description: When airlines sell more tickets than available seats, passengers can get kicked off their flights — whether they want to or not.
content: By checking in early and getting to the gate with plenty of time, you’ve done everything right. But then the airline throws a curveball, announcing an overbooked flight. Instead of boarding passengers, gate agents ask for volunteers to give up their seats. Then they stop asking and start bumping passengers off the flight. And they may call your name.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Israel and Hamas Reached a Cease-Fire Deal
description: Also, Biden is set to deliver a farewell address tonight. Here’s the latest at the end of Wednesday.
content: Officials representing Israel and Hamas said today that the two sides had agreed to a 42-day cease-fire that would coincide with the release of Israeli hostages who have been held captive in Gaza. The final details are still being worked out, but the tentative agreement raised hopes that there could soon be an end to the war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Walker and Kate Kelly
title: Transportation Hearing Will Focus on Aviation Safety and Infrastructure
description: Sean Duffy, a former Fox Business host and Wisconsin congressman, would head a sprawling Transportation Department that oversees aviation, rail and transit.
content: Sean Duffy, President-elect Donald J. Trump’s choice to lead the Department of Transportation, received bipartisan support from lawmakers on Wednesday after promising to continue efforts to improve roadway safety and address challenges with the nation’s aviation system if confirmed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Casselman
title: Inflation Sped Up in December, a Fresh Challenge for the Fed
description: The Consumer Price Index rose 2.9 percent from a year earlier, but a measure of underlying inflation was more encouraging.
content: Consumer prices rose more quickly in December, the latest sign that the Federal Reserve’s fight against inflation may have stalled.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: Two Private Moon Landers Have Launched at Once: What to Know
description: Robotic vehicles from Firefly Aerospace of Texas and Ispace of Japan parted ways early Wednesday after being launched on the same SpaceX rocket. Both are aiming for the lunar surface.
content: A space twofer took place early Wednesday morning — two lunar missions for the price of one rocket launch.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: emporium
description: This word has appeared in 45 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word emporium has appeared in 45 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Oct. 10 in “How the Impressionists Became the World’s Favorite Painters, and the Most Misunderstood” by Jason Farago:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danielle Kaye
title: F.T.C. Sues Deere Over Unfair Equipment-Repair Practices
description: The lawsuit against the maker of John Deere tractors represents a final push in the Biden administration’s broader efforts to make repairs less costly for consumers.
content: The Federal Trade Commission on Wednesday sued Deere & Company, a leading manufacturer of agricultural equipment, accusing it of unfairly preventing farmers from repairing its equipment themselves or through independent shops, driving up costs for the farmers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danielle Friedman
title: The Decade That Changed Fitness Forever
description: From 1972 to 1982, American exercise entered the modern era. Here are five workouts that changed the game.
content: From 1972 to 1982, American exercise entered the modern era. Here are five workouts that changed the game.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mira Rojanasakul and Brad Plumer
title: More Americans Than Ever Are Living in Wildfire Areas. L.A. Is No Exception.
description: Fierce winds and months of drought set the conditions for the catastrophic wildfires in Los Angeles, but the growth of housing in fire-prone areas also played a major role.
content: Fierce winds and months of drought set the conditions for the catastrophic wildfires in Los Angeles, but the growth of housing in fire-prone areas also played a major role.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aatish Bhatia, Ben Blatt, Francesca Paris, Alicia Parlapiano and Eve Washington
title: What Happened to Enrollment at Top Colleges After Affirmative Action Ended
description: Three findings from the first class to enter college without race-conscious admissions.
content: Three findings from the first class to enter college without race-conscious admissions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joanne Kaufman
title: At Home With David Rasche
description: The “Succession” actor and his wife, Heather Rasche, have made their home in Maplewood, N.J., all about family.
content: The “Succession” actor and his wife, Heather Rasche, have made their home in Maplewood, N.J., all about family.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Saurabh Datar, Ilana Marcus, Eli Murray, Ethan Singer, Alex Lemonides and Christine Zhang
title: An Extremely Detailed Map of the 2024 Election
description: See how your neighborhood voted on our interactive, precinct-level results map of the presidential election.
content: See how your neighborhood voted on our interactive, precinct-level results map of the presidential election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt, Alexandra Ostasiewicz, David Jouppi and Christina Shaman
title: Pete Hegseth’s Confirmation Hearing
description: In a hearing that stretched more than four hours, Democrats pressed Pete Hegseth, President-elect Donald J. Trump’s pick for defense secretary, on numerous allegations of misconduct, his views about women in combat and his ability to lead the department. Eric Schmitt, national security correspondent for The New York Times, explains a moment that stood out in the hearing.
content: In a hearing that stretched more than four hours, Democrats pressed Pete Hegseth, President-elect Donald J. Trump’s pick for defense secretary, on numerous allegations of misconduct, his views about women in combat and his ability to lead the department. Eric Schmitt, national security correspondent for The New York Times, explains a moment that stood out in the hearing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun, Christina Shaman and Melanie Bencosme
title: South Korean President Is Detained in Insurrection Inquiry
description: Investigators have detained South Korea’s impeached leader, Yoon Suk Yeol. This is the first time a sitting South Korean president has been detained on criminal charges. Choe Sang-Hun, the ​Seoul bureau chief for The New York Times​, explains how we got here and what it may mean for South Korea moving forward.
content: Investigators have detained South Korea’s impeached leader, Yoon Suk Yeol. This is the first time a sitting South Korean president has been detained on criminal charges. Choe Sang-Hun, the ​Seoul bureau chief for The New York Times​, explains how we got here and what it may mean for South Korea moving forward.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Axel Boada
title: Fires Continue to Burn One Week Later in California
description: The Palisades and Eaton fires, ravaging Los Angeles for more than a week, remain mostly uncontained by firefighters.
content: The Palisades and Eaton fires, ravaging Los Angeles for more than a week, remain mostly uncontained by firefighters.
source.name: The New York Times
